Models in Angular

April 25th, 2014

User Modernizr for Buttery-smooth CSS3 Animations

Animations in CSS3 are awesome, because the GPU is utilized. Unfortunately, not every browser supports them. Using Modernizr, you can target the browsers that support the CSS3 animations, and do something simpler for those that cannot.

April 24th, 2014

Always Use a Dot In ng-model

Always have a . in your ng-model. This means that Angular is updating an Object property, rather than the entire Object reference or primitive.

April 23rd, 2014

Go All-Or-Nothing on Feature Icing

There are two types of front-end features of any web application. First, there are those that are necessary. For these, you need to put in the extra work for them to function across supported devices and browsers.

February 3rd, 2014

Create Backbone-style Annotated Source Code

Backbone, Underscore and CoffeeScript have awesome annotated source code. And it’s really easy to create in your own project using Docco, a tool created by Backbone’s Jeremy Ashkenas.

Chrome Developer Tool -- Pause On Uncaught Exceptions

Ever get an vague error in the browser, but don’t quite know how to track down the culprit? A very quick way is to enable Pause execution on uncaught exceptions in Chrome Developer Tools.

January 21st, 2014

Cutting Simple Assets From Photoshop

This is a quick way to cut assets out of a PSD when you don’t need to slice specific sections of an image contained in a layer. Once you’re comfortable with the process and the keyboard shortcuts, you’ll be able to cut out an asset in less than a minute.
